title: Dangers of Poor Sleep
content: Insufficient sleep can have omnipresent effects on everything from metabolism, appetite, athletic performance, decision-making, productivity, leadership, mental health, genetics, memory, and more. It can also lead to insulin resistance and epigenetic changes. However, the effects of lost sleep can be reversible.

title: Impact of Diet and Substances on Sleep
content: The quality of sleep can be negatively affected by caffeine, alcohol, and high carb meals. The efficacy of THC and CBD as sleep aids is also discussed.

title: Sleep and Mental Health
content: Sleep and mental health have a two-way relationship. Insufficient sleep can impact mental health and vice versa.

title: Sleep and Memory
content: Sleep has a significant impact on memory. Insufficient sleep can lead to memory issues.

title: Sleep and Athletic Performance
content: Sleep has a significant impact on athletic performance. Insufficient sleep can lead to decreased performance.

title: Sleep and Covid-19
content: Sleep has a role in immune function. Good sleep hygiene is important, especially during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Effects of Insufficient Sleep
content: The omnipresent effects of insufficient sleep on everything from metabolism, appetite, athletic performance, decision-making, productivity, leadership, mental health, genetics, memory, and more. The impact of caffeine and alcohol on sleep quality, the efficacy of sleep aids such as THC and CBD.

title: Sleep and Insulin Resistance
content: Sleep and insulin resistance. Bloodstream levels of glucose are trivial compared to the amount in the muscles and liver. And if the body can't clear that glucose, it affects everything. With sleep deprivation, you have a deficit in both β cells become insensitive to spike in blood glucose and the cells become insensitive to signal of insulin.

title: Epigenetic Changes with Insufficient Sleep
content: Epigenetic changes with insufficient sleep, and the reversibility of lost sleep. They found a change in the activity of 711 genes compared to when the subjects got 8 hrs of sleep. Downregulated (impaired) genes were ones associated with the immune system. The ones upregulated genes were associated with tumor production, long-term chronic inflammation, and stress / cardiovascular disease.

title: Sleep and Cognitive Decline
content: Sleep could be an influencing factor in slowing cognitive decline. This could be because when you're sleeping, you start to eat better, exercise more and better, have more energy to make healthier choices, etc. All of these things benefit cognitive decline, so if sleep is not ultimately the thing that is transacting the cognitive benefits, maybe is it the root cause. That said, it may be playing some direct part, though, given what we’ve found about sleep and protein pathology in Alzheimer’s.

title: Sleep's Impact on Exercise Performance, Appetite, and Food Choices
content: When you are underslept, you are less likely to be motivated to be physically active. And when you do convince yourself to exercise, there is less force pressure you can generate and a reduction in the time it takes you to reach physical exhaustion up to 30%. With enough sleep, you will make better food choices, lower your caloric intake, increase calories expended, be more motivated to be active, and work out more intensely.

title: Diabetes and Sleep Apnea
content: People with untreated sleep apnea have far higher rates of diabetes. When they are treated, their diabetic profile improves markedly. But so do their food choices, their exercise, etc. so unclear if it’s a direct benefit of sleep improving cellular processes or if it’s more a higher-order issue (when well-rested, you eat better, etc.).

title: Sleep and Appetite Regulation
content: Subjects limited to 4-6 hours of sleep per night for 1 week will have downregulated leptin (the satiety hormone that signals to your brain that you are full and don’t need to eat anymore) and upregulated ghrelin (a hunger hormone signaling the body to eat more). People sleeping 6 hours a night will eat extra calories during the next day.

title: The Negative Effect of Caffeine, Alcohol, and High Carb Meals on Sleep Quality
content: Alcohol is a sedative so works like sleeping pills, but it fragments sleep so you wake up many more times during the night and it blocks REM sleep, so you wake up unrefreshed and unrestored. Caffeine blocks adenosine receptors in the brain, hitting the 'mute button' on sleepiness. If you drink a full cup of coffee at noon, quarter of that caffeine is still in the brain at midnight. A meal high in 'bad' carbohydrates (i.e. bowl of cereal) can have a harmful effect on sleep quality similar to alcohol.

title: The Efficacy of THC and CBD as Sleep Aids
content: THC is not a good sleep aid for a teenager (because their brain is still developing). THC does make you fall asleep faster (reduces sleep latency) but like alcohol, it blocks REM sleep. With regular use of THC, you start to lose the sleep latency benefit and if you try to quit using it, many people get 'rebound insomnia'.

title: CBD as a Sleep Aid
content: There’s not enough data yet on CBD as a sleep aid, although the data is more promising than THC. Early data on CBD is showing: Falling asleep faster with CBD, fewer dependency issues and don’t get insomnia rebound. CBD might also benefit some sleep disorders, might reduce severity of sleep apnea, might also help PTSD-related sleep problems. It’s dose dependent, and it’s not clear at this point what the optimal dose is. There may be other doses that are actually detrimental to sleep and we need to stay away from them.

title: CBD and Deep Sleep
content: Not enough evidence to say it definitely increases the amount of deep sleep. But there is some promising data (one single, small study). One hypothesis is that CBD may decrease your core body temperature, leading to better sleep. Another is indirect benefits through its reduction of anxiety, for which evidence is strongest right now. Anxiety is a major cause of insufficient or poor sleep. If you lower the “fight or flight” response, you get a more parasympathetic state and/or your core temperature drops.

title: Sleep and Mental Health
content: Sleep quality was suffering even though they had tried everything. But the patient was facing a difficult personal struggle. He ended up using MDMA (under clinical supervision) to deal with some of the underlying issues (trauma, anxiety, depression, etc.). The next day, and for several months now, he sleep has been fixed. The rise in anxiety has walked in lockstep with a rise in insomnia. I think we’ve got enough evidence to suggest that those two are probably not coincidental, but are significantly interrelated. It goes both ways ⇒ Mental health affects sleep, but poor sleep also affects mental health.

title: Sleep Deprivation and Mental Health
content: Deprive people of sleep, people without psychological problems can develop depression, anxiety, poor mood, etc. One single night of sleep loss can induce clinical anxiety in a person who does not normally have it. Give someone anxiety, their sleep suffers. Like Peter’s patient above, curing mental problems and you can correct sleep problems.

title: Sleep and Memory
content: There is research showing that you can boost the size and amplitude of deep sleep brain waves with electrical stimulation. Hoping to do that for the elderly and people with dementia to see if we can retain some of their learning and memory by increasing deep sleep. You place a device on your head that measures the brain waves and then sends electrical voltage into the brain. It’s essentially trying to “sing in time” with the deep sleep waves, trying to boost the size of the slow waves (which are diminished 50 to 80% in older adults). Matthew has already been able to demonstrate in young healthy adults that it can almost double the amount of memory benefit that you get from sleep.

title: Sleep's Impact on Athletes
content: Sleep really matters in Formula One car racing (or any high speed car racing, really). F1 drivers are subject to incredible jet lag having to travel across the globe for races. Sleep deprivation is going to affect margin of error and reaction time, which are essential in racing. If there is one gold standard measure of insufficient sleep, it’s not only just your response time, your basic reaction time, but it’s the number of times that you miss a response. This is called a lapse, or an error of omission (You omitted a response that should have been happening). Six hours of sleep for a week can drop your reaction time by as much as 300-400 milliseconds which in F1 racing can be the difference in being first and out of the race completely.
